grammar: Ask and answer about personal details
examples: What's your name? My name's... How old are you? I'm...
language_in_use: Ask and answer about age: How old are you? I'm five.

vocabulary: Feelings: angry, cold, happy, hot, sad, scared, sick, tired
examples: How are you? I'm happy
language_in_use: Ask and answer about feelings: Are you angry? Yes, I am. / No, I'm not.

vocabulary: Classroom objects: backpack, book, crayon, notebook, pen, pencil, pencil case, rubber
examples: This is my pen. I've got a rubber
language_in_use: Talk about your classroom objects: This is my notebook. I've got a backpack.

vocabulary: Colours: blue, brown, green, orange, pink, purple, red, yellow
examples: What colour is it? It's pink. My favourite colour is pink.
language_in_use: Ask and answer about colours: What's your favourite colour? My favourite colour is yellow.

vocabulary: Clothes: dress, jumper, shirt, shoes, skirt, socks, trousers, T-shirt
examples: My shirt is blue. My socks are red.
language_in_use: Ask and answer about clothes: I've got a new skirt. What colour is it? It's purple

vocabulary: Parts of the face and body: ear, eye, finger, hair, hand, head, leg, mouth, nose, teeth
examples: I've got two hands. This is my nose. These are my ears.
language_in_use: Talk about yourself: This is my hand. I've got two hands.

vocabulary: Family members: aunt, brother, daddy, grandma, grandpa, mummy, sister, uncle
grammar: Introduce and describe how family members feel:
examples: My brother is scared. These are my uncle and aunt. They're happy.
language_in_use: Introduce your family members to a friend: This is my brother. Hello! Nice to meet you.

vocabulary: Farm animals: cow, donkey, duck, goat, horse, rabbit, rooster, sheep
examples: What is it? It's a duck. What are they? They're sheep.
language_in_use: Ask and answer to guess an animal: Is it a cow? No, it isn't. Is it a rabbit? Yes, it is!

examples: I am Beth, I'm tall, I'm seven
language_in_use: To be questions and short answers. What's your name? How old are you? I'm...

examples: It's a pen. It's an umbrella
language_in_use: To be questions and short answers. Is it blue? Yes, it is. No, it isn't.

examples: This is my grandma. That's your grandma.
language_in_use: Who's this/that; his/her. Her name is Sally. That's his tiger.

examples: She's happy. She isn't happy
language_in_use: To be questions and short answers. Are you hungry? Yes, I am. No, I'm not.

examples: They can swim. They can't sing.
language_in_use: Can questions and short answers. Can you see the sun? Yes, I can. No, I can't.

examples: It's on the seesaw. It's next to the swing.
language_in_use: Where's the orange paint? It's next to the pencils. Where are the crayons?They're in the blue box.

grammar: Adjectives, Have got affirmative and negative
examples: I've got two legs. They haven't got ears
language_in_use: Have got questions and short answers. Have you got long hair? Yes, I have. No, I haven't.

examples: He's got a hat. She hasn't got a hat.
language_in_use: Present continuous questions and answers. What are you wearing? I'm wearing a white shirt.

examples: There's one bed. There are two beds.
language_in_use: Have got questions and short answers. Has he got a big bed? Yes, he has. No, he hasn't.

examples: I like pears. I don't like carrots.
language_in_use: These/those. These are coconuts. Those are melons.

examples: There are some crocodiles. There aren't any pandas.
language_in_use: Are there any...? Yes, there are.

examples: I play basketball. They don't play basketball.
language_in_use: Do you...? Yes, I do.

examples: It's our camera. It's their phone.
language_in_use: Whose phone is this? It's Paula's.

examples: She lives in a house. He doesn't play football.
language_in_use: Where does he live? What time does he start school?

examples: I'm watching videos. They aren't swimming.
language_in_use: What are you doing? What's he wearing?

examples: Stop! Don't run!
language_in_use: Are you playing a game? No, I'm not.

examples: I like having picnics. I don't like swimming.
language_in_use: Let's fly our kites! What about playing tennis in the park?

examples: I'd like some lemons. Would you like a watermelon?
language_in_use: Would you like to feed the lambs? I'd like to ride on a tractor.

examples: I was with grandma. We weren't hungry.
language_in_use: Were you at home yesterday? Yes, I was.

examples: I visited the zoo. They cooked.
language_in_use: Where were you on Saturday? In the morning we...

vocabulary: School subjects, Rooms and activities, Adverbs of sequence
examples: He plays… He's watching…
language_in_use: good at/not good at. I'm good at English. I'm not good at PE.

vocabulary: Chores and free time, Buildings and breakfast. Frequency expressions
examples: I always / usually / sometimes / hardly ever / never …
language_in_use: How often do you ...? Once a month.

vocabulary: Places around town, Adjectives to describe people, Family
grammar: To be: present simple or past simple?
examples: Yesterday she was sad. Today she's happy.
language_in_use: Wh-questions with was/were. Where were you on Saturday?

grammar: Countable and uncountable nouns with some/any
examples: There's some water. There isn't any water.
language_in_use: How much/many...? There's/there are... How much spinach is there? There's a lot. There isn't much.

vocabulary: Family and musical instruments, Action verbs, Dressing up
examples: Yesterday he played the drums.
language_in_use: Past simple yes/no questions. Did you like painting at kindergarten? Yes, I did.

grammar: Comparing two people, animals or objects
examples: The starfish is slower than the seahorse.
language_in_use: Superlative form of short adjectives. My dad is the tallest.

examples: He had a cake. He didn't have a cake.
language_in_use: Past simple with Wh-question form. What did you eat?

vocabulary: Objects in a history museum, Materials and objects in a house, Zoo words
examples: There was a mammoth in the cave!
language_in_use: Yes/No questions with there was/were. Were there any parrots? No, there weren't.

vocabulary: Sports clothes and equipment, Healthy eating
examples: Tom has to jump high.
language_in_use: Why...? and Because... Why do they have to...? Because they need...

examples: He's going to climb.
language_in_use: Questions with going to. Are you going to visit Spain? Yes, I am.

examples: In, on, under, behind, next to, in front of
language_in_use: Past simple question forms; verb + ...ing

examples: Want, need, like, love, don't mind
language_in_use: Verbs with to + infinitive; could/couldn't and when clauses in the past
Must and mustn't for obligation; give directions

grammar: Comparative form of long adjectives, Superlative form of long adjectives
language_in_use: Comparing two people, animals or objects

vocabulary: At the doctor's, Adjectives and verbs for staying healthy, Shops
grammar: Should and shouldn't for advice, Clauses of purpose
language_in_use: Clauses of purpose; should and shouldn't for advice

vocabulary: The natural world, Verbs and pronouns, Verbs and activities
language_in_use: Ask questions using the past continuous
Use possessive pronouns; defining relative clauses

vocabulary: Parts of plants and animals, Science and technology
language_in_use: Ask questions using will

grammar: Zero conditional, What happens if + present simple
language_in_use: What happens if + present simple

vocabulary: Physical descriptions, Pronouns and detective words, Around the house
language_in_use: Ask 'What's the matter?' and make suggestions
